description: PostgreSQL DB Overview - CPU, Memory, Disk, Settings, Connections, Locks. Metrics from postgres_exporter.

panels.description:
This panel provides an at-a-glance health check of the PostgreSQL database pods by monitoring the pg_up metric.

Up (green) indicates the database is online and responsive, while Down (red) signals a potential problem that may require investigation.
panels.title: Database Status

panels.description: This table gives CPU and memory info per container in the namespace.
panels.title: PostgreSQL Usage, Requests, Limits

panels.description: Shows how much CPU each container is using. Helps identify high CPU consumers.
panels.title: CPU Usage by Pod

panels.description: Displays the memory (RAM) used by each container. Useful for spotting memory-hungry containers.
panels.title: Memory Usage by Pod

panels.description:
Measures the total rate of data blocks (8KB chunks) requested by queries per second.

    What it includes: Both blocks found in memory (cache hits) and blocks read from disk (physical reads).

    What it means: This is a direct measure of the total data access workload or "demand" on the database. A high value indicates the database is busy serving data.

    How to interpret: This panel is most useful when viewed alongside the Cache Hit Ratio. A high read rate with a high cache hit ratio (>99%) is healthy.
panels.title: Logical Block Reads/sec

panels.description:
Measures the rate of rows (tuples) being modified by INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE commands per second.

    What it includes: The sum of all inserted, updated, and deleted rows across the database.

    What it means: This is a direct measure of the database's write workload, showing how frequently your applications are changing data.

    How to interpret: Spikes in this graph can directly correspond to application features, bulk data processing jobs, or high user activity. Consistently high values may indicate a write-intensive application.
panels.title: Tuples Modified/sec

panels.description: Tracks the time-based replication lag in seconds between the primary server and its replicas. High or consistently growing values can indicate network latency, high write load on the primary, or a replica struggling to keep up.
panels.title: PostgreSQL Replication Lag

panels.description: Provides a example to get more details of slow queries from the database.

options.content:
Pick a queryid you want to check details of from the top queries list.

1. Connect to PostgreSQL DB
2. Run Query for That queryid

```sql
SELECT queryid,
       query,
       calls,
       total_exec_time,
       rows,
       shared_blks_hit,
       shared_blks_read,
       shared_blks_dirtied,
       shared_blks_written
FROM pg_stat_statements
WHERE queryid = <copied_query_id>;
```

panels.title: Check Details of a Specific Query by queryid

panels.description: This panel identifies the top 50 SQL statements with the highest average execution time. The calculation divides the total time a query has run by its total number of calls over the selected time range, using data from pg_stat_statements. The 'Query' column shows the unique hash (queryid) for each statement, not the full SQL text. A negative queryid is a normal artifact of the hashing algorithm and has no special meaning.

targets.expr:
topk(50,
  sum by (queryid, datname) (increase(pg_stat_statements_seconds_total{cluster="$cluster",namespace="observability", datname=~"$datname", queryid=~"$queryid"}[12h]))
  /
  (sum by (queryid, datname) (increase(pg_stat_statements_calls_total{cluster="$cluster",namespace="observability", datname=~"$datname", queryid=~"$queryid"}[12h])) > 0)
)

panels.title: Top 50 Slowest Queries (by Avg Time)

panels.description: This panel identifies the top 50 SQL statements that have consumed the greatest cumulative execution time over the selected time range. It is designed to pinpoint queries contributing the most to the overall database load, based on metrics from pg_stat_statements. The 'Query' column shows the unique hash (queryid) for each statement, not the full SQL text. A negative queryid is a normal artifact of the hashing algorithm and has no special meaning.

targets.expr: topk(50, sum by (queryid, datname) (increase(pg_stat_statements_seconds_total{cluster="$cluster",namespace="observability", datname=~"$datname", queryid=~"$queryid"}[$__range])))

panels.title: Top 50 Queries by Total Execution Time

panels.description: This panel identifies the top 50 I/O-intensive SQL statements by ranking them based on their cumulative block read time. It helps pinpoint queries that read the most data from disk instead of from memory cache, which is a common performance bottleneck. The ranking is based on metrics from pg_stat_statements. The 'Query' column shows the unique hash (queryid) for each statement, not the full SQL text. A negative queryid is a normal artifact of the hashing algorithm and has no special meaning.

targets.expr: topk(50, sum by (queryid, datname) (increase(pg_stat_statements_block_read_seconds_total{cluster="$cluster",namespace="observability", datname=~"$datname", queryid=~"$queryid"}[$__range])))

panels.title: Top 50 I/O Intensive Queries (by Block Read Time)

panels.description: Shows how much of the total **requested** CPU is currently being used by the PostgreSQL pod.

targets.expr:
sum(rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container="postgresql", pod=~"postgresql-.*"}[$__rate_interval]))
/
sum(kube_pod_container_resource_requests{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container="postgresql", resource="cpu", pod=~"postgresql-.*"})

panels.title: Postgres Pod CPU Requests Usage

panels.description: Shows how much of the total CPU **limit** is being used by the PostgreSQL pod.

targets.expr:
sum(rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container=~"postgresql", pod=~"postgresql-.*"}[$__rate_interval]))
/
sum(kube_pod_container_resource_limits{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container=~"postgresql", resource="cpu", pod=~"postgresql-.*"})
* 100

panels.title: Postgres Pod CPU Limits Usage

panels.description: Shows how much of the total **requested** memory (RAM) is used by the PostgreSQL pod.

targets.expr:
sum(container_memory_working_set_bytes{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container="postgresql", pod=~"postgresql-.*"})
/
sum(kube_pod_container_resource_requests{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container="postgresql", resource="memory", pod=~"postgresql-.*"})
* 100

panels.title: Postgres Pod Memory Request Usage

panels.description: Shows how much of the total memory **limit** is being used by the PostgreSQL pod.

targets.expr:
sum(container_memory_working_set_bytes{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container="postgresql", pod=~"postgresql-.*"})
/
sum(kube_pod_container_resource_limits{cluster="$cluster", namespace="$namespace", container="postgresql", resource="memory", pod=~"postgresql-.*"}) * 100

panels.title: Postgres Pod RAM Limits Usage

title: Opstree/PostgreSQL
